content: This article may **require cleanup** to meet Wikipedia's quality standards. The specific problem is: **Information needs to be condensed and some table columns need merging to make the details column more accessible.** Please help improve this article if you can. *(July 2025)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)* The **National Monuments of Singapore**[a] are sites, buildings and structures in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) that have been designated by the [National Heritage Board](/wiki/National_Heritage_Board_(Singapore)) (NHB) as possessing exceptional historic, traditional, archaeological, architectural or artistic merit. These monuments are legally protected from demolition due to their cultural and historical significance, including associations with pivotal events such as the [Second World War](/wiki/World_War_II), the [independence of Singapore](/wiki/Independence_of_Singapore) and the nation's early development. The Preservation of Monuments Act empowers the NHB to oversee the preservation of these landmarks and encourages research as well as public engagement with Singapore's architectural heritage. The framework for designating national monuments was established under the Preservation of Monuments Act, enacted in December 1970. The act provided for the identification and legal protection of culturally significant sites, leading to the formation of the Preservation of Monuments Board (PMB) in April 1972. This body was tasked with enforcing the act amidst growing concern over the loss of heritage buildings due to rapid urban redevelopment. By mid-1973, forty sites were shortlisted for preservation and public suggestions were invited to expand the list. The initial batch of eight designated landmarks included the [Thong Chai Medical Institution](/wiki/Thong_Chai_Medical_Institution), [Armenian Church](/wiki/Armenian_Church,_Singapore), [St Andrew's Cathedral](/wiki/St_Andrew%27s_Cathedral,_Singapore), [Telok Ayer Market](/wiki/Telok_Ayer_Market), [Thian Hock Keng Temple](/wiki/Thian_Hock_Keng_Temple), [Sri Mariamman Temple](/wiki/Sri_Mariamman_Temple,_Singapore), [Fatimah Mosque](/wiki/Masjid_Hajjah_Fatimah) and the [Cathedral of the Good Shepherd](/wiki/Cathedral_of_the_Good_Shepherd). In 2021, amendments were proposed to expand the act's definition to include open spaces, inland waters and any land area associated with human activity, both past and present. The NHB, a [statutory board](/wiki/Statutory_boards_of_the_Singapore_Government) under the [Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth](/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture,_Community_and_Youth) within the [Government of Singapore](/wiki/Government_of_Singapore), is responsible for gazetting and maintaining national monuments. As of date, 83 structures have been gazetted of which 77 are formally recognised as national monuments. These include religious sites, civic buildings, marketplaces and other culturally significant landmarks across the island. The most recent addition to the list is the [38 Oxley Road](/wiki/38_Oxley_Road), officially gazetted on 12 December 2025. A comprehensive and regularly updated list of these monuments is accessible via the NHB's heritage portal. ## List of national monuments Building nameDate completedImageUsage as of 2025DetailsLocation[b]Entry number and date gazetted[c]Ref(s)[38 Oxley Road](/wiki/38_Oxley_Road)1898HouseAn eight bedroom two storey bungalow near [Orchard Road](/wiki/Orchard_Road). [Lee Kuan Yew](/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew) and his family moved into the residence after [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II), with his wife [Kwa Geok Choo](/wiki/Kwa_Geok_Choo) taking up residence there in 1950. Meetings of the [People's Action Party](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party) (PAP) were regularly held in the basement in 1954. The building continued to serve as Lee's home throughout his tenure as [prime minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Singapore), and his first born son, the third prime minister of Singapore [Lee Hsien Loong](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong), was raised there. Following Singapore's [separation from Malaysia](/wiki/Independence_of_Singapore_Agreement_1965) in 1965, fortifications and a guardhouse were added. Prior to Lee Kuan Yew's death in 2015, he expressed his intention for the house to be demolished, a position later shared by his daughter, [Lee Wei Ling](/wiki/Lee_Wei_Ling), who died in 2024, as well as his other son, [Lee Hsien Yang](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Yang). However, the government opposed the plan and subsequently gazetted it as a national monument in 2025. It remains undetermined as to which parts of the house would be demolished or retained since its elevation into a national monument. Any sort of demolition will make it the second after the [Cathay Building](/wiki/Cathay_Building) to have parts of its structure demolished.[Orchard](/wiki/Orchard)7712 December 2025[Anderson Bridge](/wiki/Anderson_Bridge_(Singapore))1910[Bridge](/wiki/Bridge)Opened in 1910, the steel [truss girder](/wiki/Truss_girder) bridge spans 204 feet (62 m) and was constructed to ease traffic on the [Cavenagh Bridge](/wiki/Cavenagh_Bridge). It is named after [Sir John Anderson](/wiki/John_Anderson_(colonial_administrator)), the [Governor of the Straits Settlement](/wiki/Governor_of_the_Straits_Settlements) from 1904 to 1911.[Singapore River](/wiki/Singapore_River) 1°17′14″N 103°51′11″E﻿ / ﻿1.28734°N 103.8531°E﻿ / 1.28734; 103.8531 7315 October 2019[Armenian Church](/wiki/Armenian_Church,_Singapore)1836[Church](/wiki/Church_(building))The Armenian Church was opened in 1836 to serve the [Armenian community](/wiki/Armenians_in_Singapore) during [colonial Singapore](/wiki/Colonial_Singapore). Designed by [George D. Coleman](/wiki/George_Drumgoole_Coleman), it resembles the [Mother Church of the Armenian Apostolic Church](/wiki/Etchmiadzin_Cathedral) in [Etchmiadzin](/wiki/Etchmiadzin), Armenia. It is Singapore's oldest church.Hill Street 006060 [Hill Street](/wiki/Hill_Street,_Singapore) 1°17′35″N 103°50′58″E﻿ / ﻿1.29310°N 103.84940°E﻿ / 1.29310; 103.84940228 June 1973[Bowyer Block](/wiki/Bowyer_Block), [Singapore General Hospital](/wiki/Singapore_General_Hospital)29 March 1926Singapore General Hospital MuseumOpened in 1926 as the Upper Block, it was built as part of the new Singapore General Hospital (SGH). It was renamed to the Bowyer Block in post-[World War II](/wiki/World_War_II) (WWII) in memory of Dr John H. Bowyer. The [neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture) building currently houses the Singapore General Hospital Museum and is the only remaining part of the original SGH.Third Hospital Avenue 0011 11 Third Hospital Avenue 1°16′50″N 103°50′11″E﻿ / ﻿1.2806°N 103.8363°E﻿ / 1.2806; 103.8363 6111 November 2009[Caldwell House](/wiki/Caldwell_House,_Singapore)1840–1841Part of the [CHIJMES complex](/wiki/CHIJMES)The Caldwell House was a [bungalow](/wiki/Bungalow) for the French sisters of [Convent of the Holy Infant Jesus Chapel](/wiki/Convent_of_the_Holy_Infant_Jesus_Chapel). Currently, the [neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture) building is part of [CHIJMES](/wiki/CHIJMES), a shopping centre. It is the oldest building in the CHIJMES compound.Victoria Street 003030 [Victoria Street](/wiki/Victoria_Street,_Singapore) 1°17′43″N 103°51′08″E﻿ / ﻿1.29540°N 103.85234°E﻿ / 1.29540; 103.85234 26 October 1990 (#23)[Cathay Building](/wiki/Cathay_Building)3 October 1939[Commercial](/wiki/Commerce)Opened in 1939, the [Art Deco](/wiki/Art_Deco) cinema was Singapore's first [skyscraper](/wiki/Skyscraper) and air-conditioned cinema. During the [Japanese occupation of Singapore](/wiki/Japanese_occupation_of_Singapore), it became an office for the [Japanese Military](/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Armed_Forces) Propaganda Department*.* As of 2025, it is the only national monument to have the building/structure demolished, but save for the façade of the original building remaining.Handy Road 00022 Handy Road 1°17′57″N 103°50′52″E﻿ / ﻿1.2993°N 103.8479°E﻿ / 1.2993; 103.8479 10 February 2003 (#48)[Cathedral of the Good Shepherd](/wiki/Cathedral_of_the_Good_Shepherd)1843–1847[Church](/wiki/Church_(building))One of Singapore's oldest cathedrals and the cathedral church for the [Archbishop of Singapore](/wiki/Archbishop_of_Singapore).4 [Queen Street](/wiki/Queen_Street,_Singapore) 1°17′46″N 103°51′05″E﻿ / ﻿1.29605°N 103.8513°E﻿ / 1.29605; 103.8513 28 June 1973 (#8)[Cavenagh Bridge](/wiki/Cavenagh_Bridge)1869[Bridge](/wiki/Bridge)Cavenagh Bridge is Singapore's oldest [suspension bridge](/wiki/Suspension_bridge) and the last major work of [Indian convicts](/wiki/Indian_indenture_system). Prior to the bridge, people had to take a ferry to cross the [Singapore River](/wiki/Singapore_River), with a temporary [toll bridge](/wiki/Toll_bridge) replacing the ferry at some point. It is named after [Sir William O. Cavenagh](/wiki/William_Cavenagh), the [Governor of the Straits Settlement](/wiki/Governor_of_the_Straits_Settlements) from 1859 to 1867.[Singapore River](/wiki/Singapore_River) 1°17′12″N 103°51′09″E﻿ / ﻿1.2866°N 103.8524°E﻿ / 1.2866; 103.852415 October 2019 (#73)[The Cenotaph](/wiki/The_Cenotaph,_Singapore)1922[War memorial](/wiki/War_memorial)A war memorial dedicated to those who died in [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I) (WWI) and [WWII](/wiki/WWII). Initially opened in 1922 to honour those from the [Colony of Singapore](/wiki/Colony_of_Singapore) who came to fight in [Europe](/wiki/European_theatre_of_World_War_I) during WWI, the reverse side of the monument was dedicated to those who died [defending Singapore](/wiki/Fall_of_Singapore) and in WW2. It is based off [The Cenotaph](/wiki/The_Cenotaph) in [Whitehall](/wiki/Whitehall), London.[Connaught Drive](/wiki/Connaught_Drive) 1°17′25″N 103°51′14″E﻿ / ﻿1.29023°N 103.85377°E﻿ / 1.29023; 103.85377 28 December 2010 (#63)[Central Fire Station](/wiki/Central_Fire_Station,_Singapore)1908[Fire station](/wiki/Fire_station)Completed in 1909, it is Singapore's oldest surviving fire station. It was built under the recommendation of the then-Superintendent of the [Singapore Fire Brigade](/wiki/Singapore_Fire_Brigade). Firefighters from the fire station responded to various post-WWII and post-independence emergencies such as the [Bukit Ho Swee fire](/wiki/Bukit_Ho_Swee_fire) and [Collapse of Hotel New World](/wiki/Collapse_of_Hotel_New_World). The 'blood-and-bandage'[d] building is still operational.Hill Street 006262 [Hill Street](/wiki/Hill_Street,_Singapore) 1°17′31″N 103°50′57″E﻿ / ﻿1.2920452°N 103.8491541°E﻿ / 1.2920452; 103.8491541 18 December 1998 (#41)[Changi Prison, Old Entrance Gate, Turret and Wall](/wiki/Changi_Prison)1936[Prison](/wiki/Prison)[Changi Prison](/wiki/Changi_Prison) started operations in 1937 as a [maximum security prison](/wiki/Supermax_prison) in response to the then-ongoing prison overcrowding problem. During the [Japanese Occupation of Singapore](/wiki/Japanese_occupation_of_Singapore), it was used as a [prisoner-of-war camp](/wiki/Prisoner-of-war_camp) where the [Double Tenth incident](/wiki/Double_Tenth_incident) took place. Much of the original building was replaced by a new building except for the entrance gate, two corner turrets, and a 180 metres (200 yd) long wall.Upper Changi Road North Upper Changi Road North 1°21′18″N 103°58′21″E﻿ / ﻿1.3550915°N 103.9724259°E﻿ / 1.3550915; 103.9724259 15 February 2016 (#72)[Chesed-El Synagogue](/wiki/Chesed-El_Synagogue)1905[Synagogue](/wiki/Synagogue)The synagogue was built by [Sir Manasseh Meyer](/wiki/Manasseh_Meyer) in 1905 as the [Maghain Aboth Synagogue](/wiki/Maghain_Aboth_Synagogue) was insufficient for the expanding [Jewish population](/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Singapore). It is currently one of two synagogues in Singapore, the other being the Maghain Aboth Synagogue.Oxley Road 00022 Oxley Rise 1°17′50″N 103°50′34″E﻿ / ﻿1.297274°N 103.8426685°E﻿ / 1.297274; 103.8426685 18 December 1998 (#38)[Chinese High School Clock Tower Building](/wiki/The_Chinese_High_School_Clock_Tower_Building)1925Part of [Hwa Chong Institution](/wiki/Hwa_Chong_Institution)Built between 1923 and 1925, the [neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture) clock tower was opened as part of [The Chinese High School](/wiki/The_Chinese_High_School_(Singapore))'s (present day [Hwa Chong Institution](/wiki/Hwa_Chong_Institution)) Bukit Timah campus, the first secondary and high school specifically for the Chinese community in Singapore.Bukit Timah Road 0673673 [Bukit Timah Road](/wiki/Bukit_Timah_Road) 1°19′35″N 103°48′12″E﻿ / ﻿1.3263581°N 103.8032904°E﻿ / 1.3263581; 103.8032904 19 March 1999 (#43)[Chung Cheng High School (Main) Administration Building and Entrance Arch](/wiki/Chung_Cheng_High_School_(Main))1965SchoolCompleted in 1968, the Administration Building of the [Chung Cheng High School's Goodman Road Campus](/wiki/Chung_Cheng_High_School_(Main)) was constructed to provide modern educational facilities for students. Chung Cheng High School was one of the first schools accessible to Chinese youths. The building combines both traditional [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_architecture) and modern architectural elements such as its double-tier Chinese roof.Goodman Road 003050 Goodman Road 1°18′17″N 103°53′27″E﻿ / ﻿1.3048356°N 103.8907128°E﻿ / 1.3048356; 103.8907128 10 July 2014 (#66)[Church of Our Lady of Lourdes](/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Lourdes_Church,_Singapore)1888[Church](/wiki/Church_(building))Opened in 1888, the [neo-gothic](/wiki/Neo-gothic) church was constructed to cater to the then-expanding [Tamil](/wiki/Tamils) [Catholic](/wiki/Catholicism) community. It is one of Singapore's oldest churches and still used to this day by different ethnicities.Ophir Road 005050 [Ophir Road](/wiki/Ophir_Road) 1°18′11″N 103°51′22″E﻿ / ﻿1.3029945°N 103.8561809°E﻿ / 1.3029945; 103.8561809 14 January 2005 (#52)[Church of Saints Peter and Paul](/wiki/St_Peter_and_St_Paul%27s_Church,_Singapore)1869–1870[Church](/wiki/Church_(building))Initially constructed to serve the growing Chinese and Tamil Catholic communities, it was designated as a church exclusively for the Chinese due to [Church of Our Lady of Lourdes](/wiki/Church_of_Our_Lady_of_Lourdes,_Singapore)'s nickname as "The Tamil Church". It is one of the oldest Catholic churches in Singapore.Queen Street 0225A225A [Queen Street](/wiki/Queen_Street,_Singapore) 1°17′52″N 103°51′05″E﻿ / ﻿1.29788°N 103.8512744°E﻿ / 1.29788; 103.8512744 10 February 2003 (#49)[Church of St Teresa](/wiki/Church_of_St_Teresa,_Singapore)7 April 1929[Church](/wiki/Church_(building))Opened in 1929 to cater to [Hokkien](/wiki/Hokkien) Catholics, it is the only Catholic building to be built have [Romano](/wiki/Ancient_Roman_architecture)-[Byzantine](/wiki/Byzantine_architecture) architecture. The Church continues to be used by different ethnicities and houses the Singapore branch of the Apostle of the Sea, an international Catholic group for seafarers.Bukit Purmei 00022 [Bukit Purmei](/wiki/Bukit_Purmei) 1°16′23″N 103°49′40″E﻿ / ﻿1.2729857°N 103.8277913°E﻿ / 1.2729857; 103.8277913 11 November 2009 (#57)[Church of the Nativity of the Blessed Virgin Mary](/wiki/Church_of_the_Nativity_of_the_Blessed_Virgin_Mary,_Singapore)1901[Church](/wiki/Church_(building))Built between 1898 and 1901, it was constructed to replace the Church of Saint Mary as the [Teochew](/wiki/Teochew_people) Catholic community in [Hougang](/wiki/Hougang) was expanding then. The Neo-Gothic church is one of the oldest churches in the suburbs of Singapore.Upper Serangoon Road 12591259 [Upper Serangoon Road](/wiki/Upper_Serangoon_Road) 1°22′25″N 103°53′54″E﻿ / ﻿1.3735529°N 103.8982627°E﻿ / 1.3735529; 103.8982627 14 January 2005 (#53)[Civilian War Memorial](/wiki/Civilian_War_Memorial)15 February 1967[War memorial](/wiki/War_memorial)Opened in 1967 by [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Singapore) [Lee Kuan Yew](/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew), the Civilian War Memorial is dedicated to those who died during the [Japanese occupation of Singapore](/wiki/Japanese_occupation_of_Singapore) in WWII. It is known as the "Four Chopsticks" by locals due to its four columns which represent the [four main ethnic groups of Singapore](/wiki/Race_in_Singapore) who died under Japanese occupation, being [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_Singaporeans), [Malays](/wiki/Malays_(ethnic_group)), [Indians](/wiki/Indian_diaspora), and [Eurasians](/wiki/Eurasian_Singaporeans).[War Memorial Park](/wiki/War_Memorial_Park,_Singapore) 1°17′34″N 103°51′17″E﻿ / ﻿1.2928954°N 103.854702°E﻿ / 1.2928954; 103.854702 15 August 2013 (#65)[Former City Hall](/wiki/City_Hall,_Singapore)1926–1929Part of the [National Gallery Singapore](/wiki/National_Gallery_Singapore)Completed in 1929, it hosted [Municipal Council](/wiki/City_Council_of_Singapore). It was where [Supreme Commander](/wiki/Supreme_Allied_Commander) of the [South East Asia Command](/wiki/South_East_Asia_Command) [Louis Mountbatten](/wiki/Louis_Mountbatten) accepted the [surrender](/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan) of General [Seishiro Itagaki](/wiki/Seishir%C5%8D_Itagaki) in 1945. In 1959, it hosted Lee Kuan Yew's swearing as Singapore's first [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Singapore) and the introductions of Singapore's national anthem "[Majulah Singapura](/wiki/Majulah_Singapura)", [state crest](/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Singapore), and [state flag](/wiki/Flag_of_Singapore). In 2015, the [neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture)-[modernist](/wiki/Modernism) building became part of the [National Gallery Singapore](/wiki/National_Gallery_Singapore) along with the [Former Supreme Court](/wiki/Former_Supreme_Court,_Singapore).Saint Andrew's Road 00033 Saint Andrew's Road 1°17′27″N 103°51′06″E﻿ / ﻿1.2907516°N 103.8517689°E﻿ / 1.2907516; 103.8517689 14 February 1992 (#25)[College of Medicine Building](/wiki/College_of_Medicine_Building)1926Occupied by the [Ministry of Health](/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Singapore)) (MOH), Singapore Medical Council, and College of Family PhysiciansThe College of Medicine Building opened as The Straits and Federated Malay States Government Medical School in 1905. In 1913 it was renamed to King Edward VII Medical School after receiving a donation from the [King Edward VII](/wiki/King_Edward_VII) Memorial Fund the year prior, then subsequently renaming itself to be King Edward VII College of Medicine in 1921. The school was merged with [Raffles College](/wiki/Raffles_College) to create the [University of Malaya](/wiki/University_of_Malaya_in_Singapore) and subsequently became the Faculty of Medicine. Currently, the [Ministry of Health](/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Singapore)) (MOH) Singapore Medical Council, and College of Family Physicians occupy the [neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture) building.College Road 001616 College Road 1°17′27″N 103°51′06″E﻿ / ﻿1.2907516°N 103.8517689°E﻿ / 1.2907516; 103.8517689 2 December 2002 (#47)[Convent of the Holy Infant Jesus Chapel](/wiki/Convent_of_the_Holy_Infant_Jesus_Chapel)1904Part of the [CHIJMES complex](/wiki/CHIJMES)Opened in 1903, the [Anglo](/wiki/English_Gothic_architecture)-[French](/wiki/French_Gothic_architecture) Gothic chapel was subsequently [consecrated](/wiki/Consecrated) in 1904, where it became the "crowning glory of the [[Convent of the Holy Infant Jesus in Singapore](/wiki/Sisters_of_the_Infant_Jesus#Singapore)]". The chapel features a five-storey [spire](/wiki/Spire) and a series of [stained-glass windows](/wiki/Stained_glass_window) made by Jules Dobbelaere, a European [craftsman](/wiki/Craftsman_(tools)). Particularly, the chapel's [apse](/wiki/Apse) features a series of windows showcasing [Jesus](/wiki/Jesus)'s life, with its [nave](/wiki/Nave) featuring the [Twelve Apostles](/wiki/Twelve_apostles). In 1983 the convent moved to a new compound in [Toa Payoh](/wiki/Toa_Payoh) and the chapel was subsequently deconsecrated. It is currently part of [CHIJMES](/wiki/CHIJMES), a shopping centre.Victoria Street 003030 [Victoria Street](/wiki/Victoria_Street,_Singapore) 1°17′43″N 103°51′08″E﻿ / ﻿1.2954026°N 103.8523427°E﻿ / 1.2954026; 103.8523427 26 October 1990 (#23)[Elgin Bridge](/wiki/Elgin_Bridge_(Singapore))1929[Bridge](/wiki/Bridge)The first Elgin Bridge was an iron bridge from [Calcutta](/wiki/Calcutta), which opened in 1862 in place of several previous bridges.[e] In 1928 the bridge was reconstructed to facilitate more traffic and to allow [*tongkangs*](/wiki/Tongkang) to pass through, which was done by raising the bridge. Spanning 140 feet (43 m) across the Singapore River, it has three steel bowstring arches and three concrete caissons on each side of the river. Elgin Bridge is named after [James B. Elgin](/wiki/James_Bruce,_8th_Earl_of_Elgin), the [Governor-General of India](/wiki/Governor-General_of_India) from 1862 to 1863.[Singapore River](/wiki/Singapore_River) 1°17′20″N 103°50′58″E﻿ / ﻿1.2890256°N 103.8493811°E﻿ / 1.2890256; 103.8493811 15 October 2019 (#73)[Former Empress Place Building](/wiki/Empress_Place_Building) (now Asian Civilisation Museum)1864–1920[Asian Civilisations Museum](/wiki/Asian_Civilisations_Museum)Completed in 1867, various government departments moved from Maxwell's House to the building, where it came to be known as the "Government Offices". It would later come to be known as the "Empress Place Building", which came from the nearby pedestrian space Empress Place and in turned was named after [Queen Victoria](/wiki/Queen_Victoria). It was turned into a history and culture museum in the 1980s. Since 2003, it has been used for the [Asian Civilisations Museum](/wiki/Asian_Civilisations_Museum). The building features [neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture) details such as [rusticated](/wiki/Rustication_(architecture)) floors, [arcaded](/wiki/Arcaded) [verandahs](/wiki/Veranda), and [Roman Doric](/wiki/Roman_Doric) façades and columns.Empress Place 00011 [Empress Place](/wiki/Empress_Place) 1°17′15″N 103°51′05″E﻿ / ﻿1.287441°N 103.8513752°E﻿ / 1.287441; 103.8513752 14 February 1992 (#29)[Former Admiralty House](/wiki/Former_Admiralty_House)1940SchoolCompleted in 1940 by [His Majesty Navy](/wiki/His_Majesty%27s_Naval_Service) Works Department, it used to house the [Commodore Superintendent](/wiki/Commodore_Superintendent) of [Sembawang Naval Base](/wiki/Sembawang_Naval_Base). After several renamings over the years,[f] it was finally renamed to the Former Admiralty House when it became a National Monument in 2002. The design of the house, often attributed to [Sir Edwin L. Lutyens](/wiki/Sir_Edwin_Lutyens), has elements of the [Arts and Crafts movement](/wiki/Arts_and_Crafts_movement). It is planned to be used for the Canberra Library as part of the [Bukit Canberra integrated development](/wiki/Bukit_Canberra).Old Nelson Road 0345345 Old Nelson Road 1°26′51″N 103°49′29″E﻿ / ﻿1.4475326°N 103.824632°E﻿ / 1.4475326; 103.824632 2 December 2002 (#45)Former Attorney-General's Chambers (now [Parliament House](/wiki/Parliament_House,_Singapore) Block C)1906Parliament House Block CThe first structure recorded on this national monument's site was an annexe of Maxwell's House, which opened in 1839. A second building emerged in the 1880s, either from the annexe demolished or incorporated into a two-storey structure. In 1976, the building was renovated house the chambers of the [Attorney-Generals](/wiki/Attorney_general). The building was restored in 1991 where it became part of the [Parliament House complex](/wiki/Parliament_House,_Singapore). In order to match the architecture of the [neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture)-styled building with surrounding buildings, a rusticated base was added.1 Parliament Place 1°17′20″N 103°51′02″E﻿ / ﻿1.28897°N 103.8505178°E﻿ / 1.28897; 103.8505178 14 February 1992 (#32)[Former Command House](/wiki/Former_Command_House)1937–1938[UBS](/wiki/UBS) UniversityBuilt c. 1937 to 1938 as the official residence of the [General Officer Commanding](/wiki/General_officer_commanding) (GOC) of [Malaya](/wiki/British_Malaya), it was originally known as the Flagstaff House. In the 1970s, the British transferred ownership of the house to the [Singapore Government](/wiki/Singapore_Government) after its military withdrew from Singapore. It later became known as the Command House, possibly a reference to being the former residence of the GOC. It is not known who designed the [Arts and Crafts movement](/wiki/Arts_and_Crafts_movement)-inspired building, with some speculating Frank W. Brewer to be the architect. It is currently houses the [UBS](/wiki/UBS) University.[*citation needed*]Kheam Hock Road 001717 Kheam Hock Road 1°19′32″N 103°49′09″E﻿ / ﻿1.3255622°N 103.8190784°E﻿ / 1.3255622; 103.8190784 11 November 2009 (#59)[Former Ford Factory](/wiki/Former_Ford_Factory) (now Memories at Old Ford Factory)1941[Museum](/wiki/Museum)Starting operations in October 1941, it was built for the Ford Motor Company of Malaya, a subsidiary of [Ford Motor Company of Canada](/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company_of_Canada). On 15 February 1942, [GOC](/wiki/General_officer_commanding) of Malaya [Arthur E. Percival](/wiki/Arthur_E._Percival) meet with General Yamashita at the Ford Plant to discuss the [British's surrender of Singapore to the Japanese](/wiki/Fall_of_Singapore#Fall_of_Singapore), where General Percival signed the surrender document in the plant's boardroom. It was subsequently handed back to Fort in 1947 and the manufacture of automobiles resumed until Ford moved out in 1980. Designed by Emile Brizay, it features [Art Deco](/wiki/Art_Deco) elements such as [bevelled](/wiki/Bevel) doorways and a flagpole rising from the building. The Former Ford Factory was one of Singapore's industrial showpiece at its completion.Upper Bukit Timah Road 0315315 [Upper Bukit Timah Road](/wiki/Upper_Bukit_Timah_Road) 1°21′10″N 103°46′08″E﻿ / ﻿1.3528265°N 103.7688399°E﻿ / 1.3528265; 103.7688399 15 February 2006 (#55)[Former Fullerton Building](/wiki/The_Fullerton_Hotel_Singapore)1928[The Fullerton Hotel](/wiki/The_Fullerton_Hotel_Singapore)Opened in 1928 as the Fullerton Building, it was named after the former Fort Fullerton, in turn named after Governor of the Straits Settlements Sir [Robert Fullerton](/wiki/Robert_Fullerton). It hosted the various government departments, with a notable one being the General Post Office. After [WWII](/wiki/WWII), it continued to house various government agencies. The building underwent renovations between 1997 to 2000 to become [The Fullerton Hotel](/wiki/The_Fullerton_Hotel_Singapore), which opened in 2001. At the time of its opening it had many "modern" facilities, such as having 14 lifts and an automated mail-sorting system.Fullerton Square 00011 Fullerton Square 1°17′10″N 103°51′11″E﻿ / ﻿1.2862286°N 103.8530281°E﻿ / 1.2862286; 103.8530281 7 December 2015 (#71)[Former Hill Street Police Station](/wiki/Old_Hill_Street_Police_Station)1934Occupied by the [Ministry of Communications and Information](/wiki/Ministry_of_Communications_and_Information) and [Ministry of Culture, Community, and Youth](/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture,_Community_and_Youth)Opened in 1934 as Hill Street Police Station and Barracks, it was built to accommodate the growth of the Singapore Police Force, which later vacated the building in December 1980. From 1983 onwards, it housed various government departments under different names. The [neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture) building was described as "the biggest and grandest of its kind in Malaya" at the time of its opening. A prominent element of this building is its windows, amounting to over 900 and are painted in bright colours.Hill Street 0140140 [Hill Street](/wiki/Hill_Street,_Singapore) 1°17′27″N 103°50′54″E﻿ / ﻿1.2907655°N 103.8482017°E﻿ / 1.2907655; 103.8482017 18 December 1998 (#39)[Former Kandang Kerbau Hospital](/wiki/KK_Women%27s_and_Children%27s_Hospital)1933 - 1955[Land Transport Authority](/wiki/Land_Transport_Authority)Dr Benjamin Sheares, who later became Singapore's second president, pioneered a surgical procedure at the hospital to create a neovagina for women born without one. NHB credited the hospital's doctors and midwives with lowering maternal and infant mortality rates and driving the post-war baby boom between 1945 and the 1960s. More than 1.2 million babies have been delivered by the time KK Hospital had relocated to the new building in 1997. The building was acquired by LTA thereafter. It housed transport exhibits such as Downtown Line, Thomson-East Coast Line and Jurong Region Line mockup train.1 Hampshire Road 1°18′29″N 103°50′58″E﻿ / ﻿1.3081622°N 103.8493114°E﻿ / 1.3081622; 103.8493114 1 October 2025 (#76)[Former Raffles College](/wiki/Raffles_College) (now NUS Campus at Bukit Timah)[g]c. 1920s[National University of Singapore (NUS) Bukit Timah Campus](/wiki/National_University_of_Singapore)Open on 22 July 1929, Raffles College was the first college for arts and sciences. In October 1946, it became part of the [University of Malaya](/wiki/University_of_Malaya) by merging with the [King Edward VII College of Medicine](/wiki/King_Edward_VII_College_of_Medicine). This increased enrolment to a point where Raffles College can no longer support the student population, resulting in the two schools to split, with the [University of Singapore](/wiki/University_of_Singapore) established in the Former Raffles College building. As of date, the Raffles College Building is used as NUS's Bukit Timah Campus.[*when?*] It is designed by [Cyril A. Farey](/wiki/Cyril_Farey) and [Graham R. Dawbarn](/wiki/Graham_Dawbarn).Waterloo Street 0024469E Bukit Timah Road 1°19′09″N 103°49′01″E﻿ / ﻿1.3190357°N 103.8169467°E﻿ / 1.3190357; 103.8169467 11 November 2009 (#56)[Former Tanjong Pagar railway station](/wiki/Tanjong_Pagar_railway_station)1932Planned to be integrated with [Cantonment MRT station](/wiki/Cantonment_MRT_station)Opened on 2 May 1932, it was built in response to the growth of passengers and goods transported by rail with the opening of the [Johor–Singapore Causeway](/wiki/Johor%E2%80%93Singapore_Causeway). Construction completed in 1931, where it was the southernmost terminal for the [Federated Malay States Railways](/wiki/Federated_Malay_States_Railways) until 30 June 2011. Designed by [Swan & Maclaren](/wiki/Swan_%26_Maclaren_Group), the [Art Deco](/wiki/Art_Deco) building was inspired by existing rail stations in [England](/wiki/England). The train terminal combines Art Deco and local architecture elements. As of date, it is undergoing works to be integrated with [Cantonment MRT station](/wiki/Cantonment_MRT_station).[*when?*]Keppel Road 003030 Keppel Road 1°16′22″N 103°50′17″E﻿ / ﻿1.2727939°N 103.8379301°E﻿ / 1.2727939; 103.8379301 9 April 2011 (#64)[Fort Siloso](/wiki/Fort_Siloso) [h]1878War museumBuilt by the British in 1878, Fort Siloso along with other forts were designed to protect the [New Harbour](/wiki/Keppel_Harbour) (present day Keppel Harbour). During the [Battle of Singapore](/wiki/Battle_of_Singapore), it was used to fight [Japanese soldiers](/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Army) and engaged in several battles. The fort was handed over to the [Singapore Armed Forces](/wiki/Singapore_Armed_Forces) in 1967 and continued to operate until 1974, when it was turned into a military museum. Designed by Colonial Engineer [Henry McCallum](/wiki/Henry_McCallum), Fort Siloso has an open artillery battery design.Siloso Road 1°15′31″N 103°48′31″E﻿ / ﻿1.2585159°N 103.808634°E﻿ / 1.2585159; 103.808634 15 February 2022 (#74)[Goodwood Park Hotel](/wiki/Goodwood_Park_Hotel) (Tower Block)1900Part of [Goodwood Park Hotel](/wiki/Goodwood_Park_Hotel)Opened in 1900 as the Deutsches Haus, it was commissioned by the Teutonia Club. The building was acquired by Jewish brothers Morris, [Ezekiel](/wiki/Ezekiel_Saleh_Manasseh), and Ellis Manasseh in 1918, where they eventually turned it into the [Goodwood Park Hotel](/wiki/Goodwood_Park_Hotel) in 1929 and converted its Tower Wing to have guestrooms. It was planned in the 1970s to reconstruct a replica of the tower's original [pinnacle](/wiki/Pinnacle), though a new pinnacle resembling the old one was constructed. The tower exhibits elements of the [Queen Anne Revival style](/wiki/Queen_Anne_revival_style), though it has been proposed that the tower may have been inspired by castles in the [Rhineland](/wiki/Rhineland), which has tall towers.Scotts Road 002222 [Scotts Road](/wiki/Scotts_Road) 1°18′32″N 103°50′04″E﻿ / ﻿1.3088916°N 103.834476°E﻿ / 1.3088916; 103.834476 23 March 1989 (#22)[Hong San See](/wiki/Hong_San_See)1908–1913[Temple](/wiki/Temple)Built between 1908 to 1913 by [Hokkien](/wiki/Hokkien) immigrants from [Nan'an](/wiki/Nan%27an,_Fujian), it was a replacement for a previous Hong San See. Several deities are worshipped in the [Hokkien architectural-styled](/wiki/Hokkien_architecture) temple, mainly [Guang Ze Zun Wang](/wiki/Guang_Ze_Zun_Wang).Mohamed Sultan Road 003131 Mohamed Sultan Road 1°17′36″N 103°50′27″E﻿ / ﻿1.2933023°N 103.8409152°E﻿ / 1.2933023; 103.8409152 10 November 1978 (#16)[House of Tan Yeok Nee](/wiki/House_of_Tan_Yeok_Nee)1885Under restorationConstructed between 1882 to 1885 by [Teochew](/wiki/Teochew_people) merchant [Tan Yeok Nee](/wiki/Tan_Hiok_Nee), it is modelled after his house in his hometown. After the Tan family moved out, it was occupied by various groups between from 1902 to 1991. As of 2022, it was sold to Indonesian businessman [Bachtiar Karim](/wiki/Bachtiar_Karim). The house was constructed under [feng shui](/wiki/Feng_shui) principles and the Teochew architecture style, such as its almost straight roof ridgesClemenceau Avenue 0207207 Clemenceau Avenue 1°17′55″N 103°50′36″E﻿ / ﻿1.2985884°N 103.843386°E﻿ / 1.2985884; 103.843386 19 November 1974 (#11)[The Istana](/wiki/The_Istana)1867–1869Residence for the [President of Singapore](/wiki/President_of_Singapore)Initiated by [Governor of the Straits Settlements](/wiki/Governor_of_the_Straits_Settlements) [Harry Ord](/wiki/Harry_Ord), it was originally known as the Government House. In 1959, it was renamed to the Istana Negara Singapura when the British handed the building to [Yang di-Pertuan Negara](/wiki/Yang_di-Pertuan_Negara) [Yusof Ishak](/wiki/Yusof_Ishak). The Istana has been the residence for the [President of Singapore](/wiki/President_of_Singapore) since 1965. The Istana Negara Singapura features [European](/wiki/European_architecture) and [Malay](/wiki/Malay_Architecture) elements in its architecture. During certain holidays, the Istana Negara Singapura is open to the public.Orchard Road[Orchard Road](/wiki/Orchard_Road) 1°18′25″N 103°50′36″E﻿ / ﻿1.307007°N 103.8432241°E﻿ / 1.307007; 103.8432241 14 February 1992 (#24)[Istana Kampong Gelam](/wiki/Istana_Kampong_Glam)1839–1843Occupied by [Malay Heritage Centre](/wiki/Malay_Heritage_Centre)Completed in 1843, it was commissioned by then-[Sultan of Johor-Lingga-Riau](/wiki/Sultan_of_Johor) [Hussein Shah](/wiki/Hussein_Shah_of_Johor)'s son, [Tengku Mohammed Ali](/wiki/Ali_Iskandar_of_Johor). The building continued to house Ali's descendants until the 1990s, where it was renovated from 1999 to 2004 to be the [Malay Heritage Centre](/wiki/Malay_Heritage_Centre), which opened in 2005. The Istana Kampong Gelam features elements of [European](/wiki/European_architecture) and [Malay](/wiki/Malay_Architecture) architecture.Sultan Gate85 Sultan Gate6 August 2015 (#70)[Jurong Town Hall](/wiki/Jurong_Town_Hall)1971–1974CommercialConstructed between 1971 to 1974, it was built as the [JTC](/wiki/JTC_Corporation)'s headquarters during the expansion of [Jurong](/wiki/Jurong) Town. As of 2018, Jurong Town Hall is used as a space for start-up companies. The geometric building was designed to symbolise the success of Singapore's [industrialisation](/wiki/Industrialisation) programme.Jurong Town Hall Road9 [Jurong Town Hall Road](/wiki/Jurong_Town_Hall_Road)2 June 2015 (#69)Former Keng Teck Whay Building (now Singapore Yu Huang Gong)1847–1875[Temple](/wiki/Temple)Established in 1831 by [Straits Chinese](/wiki/Straits_Chinese) merchants from Malacca, Keng Teck Whay is one of the earliest [benefit societies](/wiki/Benefit_societies) established in Singapore. The building itself features Hokkien architectural elements, such as its curved roof ridge. There are also three structures within the Keng Teck Whay Building: an entrance gateway, an octagonal [pagoda](/wiki/Pagoda), and a hall. Ownership of the building was transferred to a [Taoist](/wiki/Taoism) organisation in 2010, where they renamed it to Singapore Yu Huang Gong and opened it as a temple in 2015.Telok Ayer Street 0150150 [Telok Ayer Street](/wiki/Telok_Ayer_Street)11 November 2009 (#58)[Lim Bo Seng Memorial](/wiki/Lim_Bo_Seng_Memorial)1954War memorialOpened in 1954, it commemorates [WWII](/wiki/WWII) resistant fighter [Lim Bo Seng](/wiki/Lim_Bo_Seng). Designed by [Ng Keng Siang](/wiki/Ng_Keng_Siang), it is a combination of [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_architecture) and [modern](/wiki/Modern_architecture) architecture, such as its Chinese-style roof on top of a concrete structure.Connaught Dr Connaught Dr6328 December 2010[MacDonald House](/wiki/MacDonald_House)1949Occupied by [Citibank](/wiki/Citibank)Constructed between 1948 to 1949 as a new branch office for [HSBC](/wiki/HSBC), it was named after Governor-General of Malaya [Malcolm John MacDonald](/wiki/Malcolm_John_MacDonald). The building is known to be the site of [a bombing in 1965](/wiki/MacDonald_House_bombing). The [Modernist](/wiki/Modernism) and [utilitarian](/wiki/Utilitarian_(architecture)) building was one of the tallest buildings in Singapore at the time of its opening and the first air-conditioned office building in [Southeast Asia](/wiki/Southeast_Asia).Orchard Road 0040A40A [Orchard Road](/wiki/Orchard_Road)5010 February 2003[Maghain Aboth Synagogue](/wiki/Maghain_Aboth_Synagogue)1878[Synagogue](/wiki/Synagogue)Consecrated on 4 April 1878, it was built for the expanding [Jewish population in Singapore](/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Singapore). The synagogue was only initially for men as Jewish men and women pray separately. A wooden gallery was added for women to pray, which was later turned into a permanent one in 1925. The Jacob Ballas Centre opened next to the Maghain Aboth Synagogue in 2007. The [neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture)-synagogue's interior focuses on the [ark](/wiki/Ark_of_the_Covenant).Waterloo Street 002424 [Waterloo Street](/wiki/Waterloo_Street)3527 February 1998[Masjid Abdul Gaffoor](/wiki/Masjid_Abdul_Gaffoor)1907[Mosque](/wiki/Mosque)Commencing construction in 1907, it was to replace the Al-Abrar Mosque on [Telok Ayer Street](/wiki/Telok_Ayer_Street). It was named after Shaik Abdul Gafoor, who initiated its construction. The mosque features [Saracenic](/wiki/Saracenic_architecture) elements, such as its [cinquefoil arches](/wiki/Multifoil_arch) in its prayer hall, as well as [Neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture) elements, such as [Corinthian](/wiki/Corinthian_pillar) and [Doric](/wiki/Doric_order) pillars. It is largely used by [Tamil Muslims](/wiki/Tamil_Muslim).Dunlop Street 004141 Dunlop Street185 July 1979[Masjid Al-Abrar](/wiki/Masjid_Al-Abrar)1829[Mosque](/wiki/Mosque)Completed in 1855, the Masjid Al-Abrar replaced a small hut with the same name. Between 1986 to 1989, the mosque expanded. Built in the [Indo-Islamic architectural style](/wiki/Indo-Islamic_architecture), it features two [star and crescent](/wiki/Star_and_crescent)-cladded octagonal minarets next to its entrance. Initially used mainly by those from the [Chulia](/wiki/Keling#Singapore) community, the Masjid Al-Abrar still serves [Indian muslims](/wiki/Indian_Muslims), though muslims from other communities have also prayed at the mosque.Telok Ayer Street 0192192 [Telok Ayer Street](/wiki/Telok_Ayer_Street)1019 November 1974[Masjid Alkaff Upper Serangoon](/wiki/Masjid_Alkaff_Upper_Serangoon)1932[Mosque](/wiki/Mosque)Opened in 1932, plans for the mosque were ready by 1927, though the death of a partner for the firm that was meant to design to mosque delayed the project. The Masjid Alkaff Upper Serangoon is built in multiple architectural styles, such as [Moorish-styled arches](/wiki/Moorish_architecture), [Corinthian columns](/wiki/Corinthian_columns), and [Neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture) coffered ceilings.Pheng Geck Avenue 6666 Pheng Geck Avenue6818 December 2014[Masjid Hajjah Fatimah](/wiki/Masjid_Hajjah_Fatimah)1846[Mosque](/wiki/Mosque)Commissioned in 1845 by [Hajjah Fatimah](/wiki/Hajjah_Fatimah), it was her thanksgiving to [Allah](/wiki/Allah) for not being harmed when burglars broke into her home. Built in the [Indo-Islamic architectural style](/wiki/Indo-Islamic_architecture), it also has some European features. A feature of the mosque is its octagonal minaret tower, which began to tilt after it was completed. Even though repairs were carried out, it still leaned slightly, giving it the moniker the "Leaning Tower of Singapore".Beach Road 40014001 [Beach Road](/wiki/Beach_Road,_Singapore)728 June 1973[Masjid Jamae](/wiki/Masjid_Jamae)1830[Mosque](/wiki/Mosque)South Bridge Road 0218218 [South Bridge Road](/wiki/South_Bridge_Road)1319 November 1974[Masjid Sultan](/wiki/Masjid_Sultan)1928[Mosque](/wiki/Mosque)Muscat Street 00033 Muscat Street148 March 1975[Ministry of Labour Building, Old](/wiki/Old_Ministry_of_Labour_Building), currently the Subordinate Courts Family and Juvenile Division1928GovernmentHavelock Square 00033 Havelock Square3627 February 1998[Nagore Durgha](/wiki/Nagore_Durgha,_Singapore)1893[Shrine](/wiki/Shrine)Telok Ayer title: National monuments of Singapore
